key_insight: Pretrained vision-language models (VLMs) can serve as accurate perceptual judges by replicating human binary preference judgments, enabling human-aligned image compression without large psychophysical training sets.
problem_solved: Traditional distortion metrics (e.g., MSE) and bespoke perceptual networks often fail to match human preferences; collecting and training on large-scale human judgments is expensive and slow. This work provides a scalable alternative for perceptual evaluation and loss.
method: Use off-the-shelf VLMs to compare original vs. compressed images and predict binary human preference signals.
Convert VLM preference outputs into a perceptual evaluation metric (and optionally a differentiable loss) for training or selecting compression models.
Calibrate VLM outputs to align with human binary judgments so the model can be used as a reliable proxy judge.
impact: This approach offers a scalable, plug-in perceptual judge that lets practitioners optimize compressors for human-perceived quality without costly psychophysical labeling, improving perceived quality at comparable bitrates and speeding development cycles.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: original image → compressor → compressed image → VLM comparator → binary human-like judgment
Scatter/line plot: bitrate vs. perceived quality comparing MSE-optimized, perceptual-loss-optimized, and VLM-aligned compression
Agreement bar chart: percent agreement between VLM judgments and human raters across conditions
Icon set: human judge, VLM (brain+vision+language), compression (file/bitrate), and a checkmark indicating alignment
paper_title: VLIC: Vision-Language Models As Perceptual Judges for Human-Aligned Image Compression
paper_authors: Kyle Sargent, Ruiqi Gao, Philipp Henzler, Charles Herrmann, Aleksander Holynski
